instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not turning powering up
threads.message:
This board came in with no sign of liquid damage but won't power up. Only things i've found so far is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> reading 2.8 and the ssd chips are warm (not hot), but the red spot in the picture is ready about 104 degrees (F). So i ran the board through the ultrasonic just case there were some hidden corrosion, no change in temp or voltage reading of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>. With lifeboat board taken out, the ssd isn't warm anymore. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is 5.1.

other measurements noticed in comparison to another board with other issues is LA640 and 650 are both reading 1.8ohm and on the another board i get 4ohms. Not sure if this means sometime

Any suggestions

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not turning powering up
threads.message:
"but the red spot in the picture is ready about 104 degrees (F)"
Which picture?

GPU and CPU core rails may have small differences in resistance to ground; depending of exact chip type.
But if you have exact same chips in two boards, the readings should be very close.

What is the CPU core behaviour?
Do you note a drop to 0.6V from 1V or so?

Without J9600, <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> still low?
Post <CHIP>U8295</CHIP> voltages.

BTW, as you get even S0 voltages, board turns on; doesn't boot is the problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not turning powering up
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not turning powering up
threads.message: That is a ground, or unconnected pad...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not turning powering up
threads.message:
No activity on cpu core rails.
Without J9600, <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> still low at 2.8

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> - 0.12
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>P3V3S0_CAP</SIGNAL> - 1.7

Measured pin 5 of <CHIP>U8295</CHIP> and it's shorted to ground. Searching for the source now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not turning powering up
threads.message:
Remove the chip and check if short disappears.
If yes, change <CHIP>U8295</CHIP>.
If not, continue to search for the culprit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not turning powering up
threads.message:
Believe I've isolated the short to <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. It shorts out <CAPACITOR>C2975</CAPACITOR> to 78. The short is also present on L2950. With L2950 pulled, pin 1 reads 1.20ohms while pin 2 which also ties back to <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> reads 40ohms.
Before i pull this chip, any suggestion on what stencil to get for this chip and possibly where i can get it?
Can I remove this chip/disable it and the board still run, just without J3300 and if so, do you happen to know how to disable it so it's not looked at by the system?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not turning powering up
threads.message:
Try to separate <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> from the power rails where it generates short.
And check if the behavior changes.
